div1.head: Letter fragment from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, June 14, 1890
div1.p:

was so drunk that she dropped
the baby on its head on the cobble-
stone. The baby rolled into the
gutter, insensible, and probably dead.
At any rate it must have died
soon after. I have been walking
around in all parts of the town
and I have seen many other
disgusting sights but as I learn
want to learn all I can of the
people here. I persist in it,
although it is anything but a
pleasure.

It amuses me to hear the people
here speak of the glory of old Scotland
and talk of the union with England
as a calamity. What would Scotland
be but for its proximity to England.
Nothing, or worse,

Please find out what would be a good
wedding present for me get for Jess and
Christine. I might be able to do
something to more advantage in
London or Paris than in New York.
You must be careful of yourself so as
not to take those colds. The climate
of Pittsburgh is very changeable.

Here it is cold all the time. The
east wind is very penetrating.

The course in Anatomy which I
am taking is very fine. There are three
demonstrations every day and two
examinations each week, one is on
each mans dissection and the other
on the subjects treated on in the
demonstrations both, are oral,
and on the cadaver. The instructors
are all excellent men and spare
no pains in trying to make you learn
the subject. They really teach. In
New York they lecture and give you
a chance learn if you happen to
feel like listening. Here they give
attention to each man separately.

I am sure that I have done a
good thing in coming here for this
course. Although the anatomy
is so f superior here, I am told by
the New York fellows who have seen
operations here, that they are not
up to New York in Surgery. Waring
was very much shocked the loose
and dirty way they went at their
work.

The excellency of the anatomy is chiefly
due to the energy and enthusiasm
of the professor, Sir William Turner

Everyday, he comes into the dissecting
room and goes to each man who
is working there. He is an easy
pleasant talker and a fine dissector.

He always asks you a few questions
then shows you some points about the
dissection and then gives you some
information, about surgical operations
in the region you are dissecting
usually mentioning some particular
case. I am dissecting the axilla
and yesterday he explained about
the operation which resulted fatally
on young Lincoln, it being in the
region of the axilla. Besides the professor
there are always half a dozen demonstra-
tors in the room who are always
ready to tell anything you want
to know.

I think that before I leave Scotland.
I shall take a day up in the lakes.
I can make a trip through the Trossacks
Loch Katrine and Loch Lomond all
in a day and for about five dollars.
I received a “Bulletin” yesterday from
Uncle Tom, I am always glad to get
the papers. The American news in the
Edinburgh papers is confined to the
stock quotations, cyclones and railway
wrecks. They The people here think
that we have a trouble climate in
America, and that we are in
constant peril from tornadoes etc.
